conclusion: To predict which container (E, F, or G) the liquid will flow into after passing through the baffles, the setup needs to be analyzed step by step.
Liquid flows downward from A and hits the black baffle, which is angled to direct the liquid toward the left side.
Liquid flows downward from B and hits the black baffle, which directs the liquid toward the left side, merging with the liquid from A.
Liquid flows downward from C and hits the yellow baffle, which is angled to direct the liquid toward the center-right side.
Liquid flows downward from D and hits the gray baffle, which is angled to direct the liquid toward the far-right side.
Liquid from A and B merges and flows leftward due to the black baffle, then flows downward and enters container E (green).
Liquid from C is directed by the yellow baffle toward the center-right side, flows downward, and enters container F (red).
Liquid from D is directed by the gray baffle toward the far-right side, flows downward, and enters container G (white).
Based on the angles of the baffles and the flow paths, liquid from A and B flows into container E, liquid from C flows into container F, and liquid from D flows into container G.
Final answer: Container E receives liquid from A and B, container F receives liquid from C, and container G receives liquid from D.
